history.content:
Yes. It'll make the lives of your TAs and Readers a lot easier, and it's absolutely necessary if you want to get involved with research or go to grad school. Plus if you're already CS-minded, it's not difficult at all to pick up on.

--

I'll just add a quick edit. Latex is very useful for 170 and 70, because you end you doing a lot of explaining and proving which is a lot of words. That is easier to type. Other classes like ee16a also ask for latex, but I always found that much much more difficult and takes up so much time that it wasn't worth it for me. 

--

I'd add that LaTeX is pretty easy to learn as you need it. For the first few weeks, it may feel like it's slowing you down, but you'll quickly find your own favorite packages (LaTeX formatting tools) and life will suddenly become easier.

--

To give a differing viewpoint: I don't think learning LaTeX specifically is as important, as opposed to having some way of writing / submitting pretty-looking equations (and pseudocode, for 170). For example, I got through most of my classes using Microsoft Word's built-in equation editor, which basically functions exactly the same way that LaTeX does (including having mostly the same set of commands). I only switched to using LaTeX in my last year, mostly because I was already used to it when writing homework/exam problems for 170 / answering questions on Piazza, and Microsoft Word lags massively when you fill up an entire page with equations.

Other than submitting homework, I've found it useful even when working out computations / as a scratchpad, if the computation becomes too complicated to easily read in Notepad.

Just don't handwrite your answers. (Also: Google docs' equation editor is terrible.)

Yes. It'll make the lives of your TAs and Readers a lot easier, and it's absolutely necessary if you want to get involved with research or go to grad school. Plus if you're already CS-minded, it's not difficult at all to pick up on.

--

I'll just add a quick edit. Latex is very useful for 170 and 70, because you end you doing a lot of explaining and proving which is a lot of words. That is easier to type. Other classes like ee16a also ask for latex, but I always found that much much more difficult and takes up so much time that it wasn't worth it for me. 

--

I'd add that LaTeX is pretty easy to learn as you need it. For the first few weeks, it may feel like it's slowing you down, but you'll quickly find your own favorite packages (LaTeX formatting tools) and life will suddenly become easier.

Yes. It'll make the lives of your TAs and Readers a lot easier, and it's absolutely necessary if you want to get involved with research or go to grad school. Plus if you're already CS-minded, it's not difficult at all to pick up on.

--

I'll just add a quick edit. Latex is very useful for 170 and 70, because you end you doing a lot of explaining and proving which is a lot of words. That is easier to type. Other classes like ee16a also ask for latex, but I always found that much much more difficult and takes up so much time that it wasn't worth it for me.

Yes. It'll make the lives of your TAs and Readers a lot easier, and it's absolutely necessary if you want to get involved with research or go to grad school. Plus if you're already CS-minded, it's not difficult at all to pick up on.
For classes like CS70/170, I've heard that Latexing makes life easier. Is it worth the time investment to learn to do this? Thanks.
history.subject: Should I learn Latex?
